deceased.title: Deaths [until 3/26/2023]
deceased.disclaimer: Note: deceased by age and retirement homes data is provided weekly, therefore it is not complete for last two weeks.

patients.title: Hospitalizations (c19 units and red zones) [until 3/31/2023]
patients.disclaimerCare: Note: nursing hospitals are not reporting daily state since April 8, 2021.

patientsAge.title: Hospitalizations (SARI) by Age, weekly
patientsAge.disclaimer: This only includes hospitalisations tracked in the EPISARI system, which excludes COVID-19 admissions without severe acute respiratory infections.

hCenters.title: Healthcare Center Treatment [until 10/25/2020]
hCenters.disclaimer: Note: this chart is not up-to-date. From October 25, 2020, Ministry of Health does not report data about health centers as they are not collected anymore.

hcCases.title: Cases in Health Care and Retirement Homes, weekly [until 3/26/2023]
hcCases.disclaimer: Note: data for last week are not complete yet - share of health care employees may be smaller than actual.

tests.title: Testing
tests.disclaimer: Note: From 1 February 2022, a positive result on PCR or RAT test is considered a confirmed case. Persons who are additionally tested with the PCR test after a positive RAT test are not included in the statistics of positive RAT.

infections.title: Structure of Confirmed Cases [until 3/31/2023]
infections.disclaimer: Note: from October 11, 2020, NIJZ does not report the data about employees in retirement homes and healtcare anymore.

spread.doublingRateLabel: In how many days does the number of infected people double

regions.title: By Region [until 4/2/2023]
regions.disclaimer: Note: deceased by region data is provided weekly, therefore it is not complete for last two weeks.

map.title: Municipality Map [until 4/2/2023]
map.disclaimerRegion: Note: deceased by region data is provided weekly, therefore it is not complete for last two weeks. This is the reason why there is a deviation with the total number of deaths.
map.disclaimer: Note: deceased by municipality data is not provided by NIJZ since December 12 and even before it is not complete. This is the reason why there is a deviation with the total number of deaths.

europe.statusOrange: recovered/vaccinated or negative PCR/RAT test or 7-day quarantine

ageGroups.disclaimer: Note: demographic data (gender, age) about the deceased is reported by NIJZ weekly. This is the reason why there is a deviation with the total number of deaths.

absolute.title: Yearly comparison

excess.title: Excess relative to years 2015-19
excess.covidDeathsMZ: COVID-19 deaths in hospitals and DSO-jih (Government)
excess.disclaimer: Note: data on deaths for the last displayed week is incomplete. You can read more about the chart in the article

excessByAgeGroup.title: Excess relative to years 2015-19 by age groups
excessByAgeGroup.disclaimer: Note: data on deaths for the last month is incomplete. Column widths represent the ratio between deaths in the age group of the column versus all deaths in a given month.

vaccination.title: Vaccination by Age Groups [until 7/5/2022]
vaccination.disclaimer: Note: the chart shows the share of the population that was fully vaccinated in the previous 6 months or have received an additional dose of the vaccine. Protection is considered to be effective 14 days after receiving this dose and lasts 6 months from that date.

vaccineEffect.title: Vaccination Effect [until 3/31/2023]
vaccineEffect.confirmedCasesAbs: From {{ startDate, %b %e %Y }} to {{ endDate, %b %e %Y }}, **{{protectedC}}** ({{protectedPct}}) persons fully protected with vaccination and **{{otherC}}** ({{otherPct}}) other persons (unvaccinated, partially vaccinated) were among the confirmed cases. Among protected with vaccination (fully vaccinated at least 14 days ago), infection was confirmed in **{{protectedToDatePct}}** ({{protectedC}} out of {{totalProtected}}).
vaccineEffect.hospitalizedCasesAbs: From {{ startDate, %b %e }} to {{ endDate, %b %e %Y }}, **{{protectedC}}** ({{protectedPct}}) persons fully protected with vaccination and **{{otherC}}** ({{otherPct}}) other persons (unvaccinated, partially vaccinated) were hospitalized. Among protected with vaccination (fully vaccinated at least 14 days ago), **{{protectedToDatePct}}** were hospitalized ({{protectedC}} out of {{totalProtected}}). Data by two age groups (<65, 65+) are available in [this chart](/en/stats#vaccine-effect-age-chart).
vaccineEffect.icuCasesAbs: From {{ startDate, %b %e %Y }} to {{ endDate, %b %e %Y }}, **{{protectedC}}** ({{protectedPct}}) persons fully protected with vaccination and **{{otherC}}** ({{otherPct}}) other persons (unvaccinated, recovered, partially vaccinated) were addmitted in intensive care unit.
vaccineEffect.confirmedCasesRatio: Among the confirmed cases, there are **{{multiple}}** times as many unvaccinated and partially vaccinated as fully protected with vaccination.
vaccineEffect.hospitalizedCasesRatio: Unvaccinated and partially vaccinated are hospitalized **{{multiple}}** times as many as fully protected with vaccination. Data by two age groups (<65, 65+) are available in [this chart](/en/stats#vaccine-effect-age-chart) and they show even higher efficiency.
vaccineEffect.icuCasesRatio: Unvaccinated, recovered and partially vaccinated are admitted in intensive care unit **{{multiple}}** times as many as fully protected with vaccination.
vaccineEffect.disclaimer: Due to the different vaccination rates in the individual age groups, this interpretation should be taken with caution - read more about the Simpson's paradox in [this article](https://medium.com/sledilnik/ko-u%C4%8Dinkovita-cepiva-naletijo-na-statisti%C4%8Dni-paradoks-4fd9c154086e).
vaccineEffect.disabled: Note: We cannot update this data since January 17, 2022 due to change in reporting.

vaccineEffectAge.title: Hospitalization Rates (SARI) by Vaccination Status and Age Group [until 7/5/2022]
vaccineEffectAge.disclaimer: This chart presents so-called [Simpson's paradox](https://medium.com/sledilnik/ko-u%C4%8Dinkovita-cepiva-naletijo-na-statisti%C4%8Dni-paradoks-4fd9c154086e) caused by differences in vaccination rates and risk levels in different age groups - more information in [this article](https://medium.com/sledilnik/ucinek-cepljenja-8167a2e2b179).

schoolStatus.title: Situation in School and Kindergarten [until 4/5/2022]
schoolStatus.disclaimer: Note: the data is reported to the ministry by the schools themselves, and may be incomplete. Data collected until 4/5/2022.
schoolStatus.regionsWithChanges: Changes regime in school or kindergarten in the past week by region:
schoolStatus.noData: There is no data about absence due to (suspected) infection or changed regime for this school unit.

Easing of restrictions: gathering up to 500 people, spectators on sport events.

quarantineStrict.title: Quarantine

A tighter mandatory 14-day quarantine for all entrants from critical countries.
(red zone BIH, Serbia, Kosovo)

gatherings50.title: Up to 50

gatherings10.title: Up to 10

croatia.title: Croatia
croatia.description: Croatia on the red list, strict 14 day quarantine on return

allSchools.title: Schools
allSchools.description: All schools reopened for new school year

masks.title: Masks
masks.description:
Face masks required in all indoor public places and outdoors when distance less than 2m.
Restaurants open only until 22:30.

testOrQuarantine.title: Test
testOrQuarantine.description: Negative test or 10-day quarantine on entrance from countries in red or orange list

regions.title: Regions
regions.description: Restrictions for red regions: movement outside municipal borders, use of masks outside, restriction of some services

schools6+.title: Schools 6+
schools6+.description: Remote schooling for elementary schools from grade 6, secondary and music schools

movement.title: 🚫21-6h
movement.description:
Movement restricted between 21:00-6:00. Movement restricted to own region.
Gathering up to 10 people. Restriction of all events.

restaurants.title: Restaurants
restaurants.description:
Closure of restaurants, hotels, shopping centers, hair and beauty shops.
Closure of student homes, reduced public transportation.

municipality2.title: Municipalities
municipality2.description: Prohibition of movement outside municipal borders

liftLibraries.title: Libraries
liftLibraries.description: Easing of restrictions: libraries, service workshops, construction and maintenance services, …

liftShops.title: Shops
liftShops.description: Easing of restrictions: technical, car, furniture in children's shops, pedicure, photocopier, jewelry and watch shops

gatherings2.title: Gatherings
gatherings2.description: Prohibition of gathering in public places (except for close family members)

services.title: Services
services.description:
Prohibition of all shops and services to consumers (exceptions: groceries, pharmacies, banks, post offices, …)
The suspension of public transport (exception: taxi). Removal of some exceptions for border crossings.

planRelaxation.title: Plan
planRelaxation.description: Government has accepted the plan of relaxation of measures in five phases.

alcoDrinks.title: Alcohol
alcoDrinks.description: Prohibition of alcohol and alcohol drinks in take away restaurants and similar.

liftServices.title: Services
liftServices.description:
Easing of restrictions: public transport (limited service), florist, car-wash, cleaners.
In 4 regions also shops with cloths and shoes and movement inside region borders with app.

liftReligiousCeremonies.title: Rel.c.
liftReligiousCeremonies.description:
Easing of restrictions: religious ceremonies allowes with some restrictionsob. Libraries, maintenance, installation.
In 4 regions also museums, book stores, specialized stores.

services2.title: Services
services2.description:
Prohibition of all shops and services to consumers (exceptions: groceries, pharmacies, banks, post offices, …).
Relaxation of some restrictions on gathering and movement until 25.12. 20:00.

liftFoodMarkets2.title: Markets
liftFoodMarkets2.description: Easing of restrictions: food markets, news-stands, hairdressing salons.

liftGym.title: Gym
liftGym.description:
Easing of restrictions: individual and guided recreation with restrictions
(1 person per 50m2 and 5m interpersonal distance).

planRelaxation2.title: Plan
planRelaxation2.description: Government has accepted the revised plan of relaxation of measures in five phases.

gym.title: Gym
gym.description:
Closure of gyms, pools, sport facilities (with exceptions).
Closing of museums and galleries. Libraries open only for pick-up.

liftRegions.title: Regions
liftRegions.description: Easing of restrictions: shops for children, museums, galleries, libraries and ski-resorts are open in some regions.

liftSchools3.title: Schools 3
liftSchools3.description: Easing of restrictions: kindergarten and elementary school up to 3rd grade in some regions (all but Gorizia, Lower Sava and Southeast Slovenia region).

closeSchools3.title: Schools 3
closeSchools3.description:
Closed kindergarten and elementary school up to 3rd grade in Coastal–Karst and Central Sava region.
Allowed selling of 🧦 and 🩲 in grocery shops.

bordersStrict.title: Borders
bordersStrict.description: Less exceptions for entering the country without negative test or quarantine.

liftShops2.title: Shops
liftShops2.description:
Easing of restrictions: all shops up to 400 m2, cosmetic services, individual education,…
(negative test of customers and/od employees required for some services)

liftSchools3All.title: Schools 3
liftSchools3All.description: Easing of restrictions: kindergarten and elementary school up to 3rd grade in all regions.

liftBorders.title: Borders
liftBorders.description: No checkpoints on borders, quarantine and negative test not required for vaccinated and recovered.

liftMunicipality2.title: Municipalities
liftMunicipality2.description:
Easing of restrictions: free movement between municipalities and regions, gathering og up to 10 people, all shops.
Opened elementary schools (all) and high-schools for last grade, allowed exams and group excersises up to 10 people on university.
Contactless sport and recreational excersises in groups of up to 10 people allowed with distance of 2m.

okRed.title: Coastal–K.
okRed.description: Coastal–Karst region: gathering forbidden, closure of some shops, limited movement to/from other regions.

liftHighSchools.title: H.schools
liftHighSchools.description:
Easing of restrictions: high-school grade 1-3 opened (model C), opened dormitories. Opening of terraces and cafes in Southeast Slovenia in Lower Sava region.
Checkpoints on borders, quarantive or negative test after five days.

liftOkPn.title: Coastal–K.
liftOkPn.description:
Coastal–Karst region: movement to/from other regions allowed. Littoral–Inner Carniola region: opening of terraces and cafes.
Allowed religious rites for up to 10 people in smaller churches and religious education.

okGoKoRed.title: Red 3
okGoKoRed.description:
Coastal–Karst, Gorizia, Carinthia regions: limited movement to/from other regions.
HAT test is not accepted as proof to enter the country or to shorten the quarantine. Movement restricted between 22:00-5:00.

bordersClosed.title: Borders
bordersClosed.description:
Travel restricted to red zones (allowed for vaccinated and recovered).
Strict border regime (only PCR from EU/Schengen countries, border crossing only on checkpoints).

elevenDays.title: 11 Days
elevenDays.description:
Social gatherings ban (incl. weddings, celebrations, religious ceremonies). A closure of all schools and kindergartens as well as non-essential shops
(except for food stores and markets, technical stores and garden centres). Travel between different Slovene regions is banned.
Mandatory use of masks outdoors except for sport activities on green areas.

liftEaster.title: Easter
liftEaster.description:
Easter lockdown measures: Travelling between regions and family visits are allowed between 5 am and 10 pm
in a group of up to 6 people from 2 households (children under 15 are not included in the restrictions). All other curfew rules remain in place.

liftMasksOutside.title: Masks
liftMasksOutside.description: Easing of restrictions: use of face masks outdoors not required if distance between persons can be maintained at at least 1.5 meters.

liftMovement.title: 🚫22-5h
liftMovement.description:
Easing of restrictions: no movement restricition between 22:00-5:00. Kindergarten, elementary schools and high-schools (model C).
Libraries, galleries, museums, all shops and most services. Sport and recreational excersises in groups of up to 10 people.

liftTerrace.title: Terrace
liftTerrace.description:
Easing of restrictions: Outdoor drinking and dining is allowed from 7AM to 7PM in 8 regions.
Allowed organized public outdoor gatherings of up to 100 people.

liftRegions2.title: Regions
liftRegions2.description: Easing of restrictions: free movement between regions, gathering up to 10 people.

liftTerrace2.title: Terrace
liftTerrace2.description:
Easing of restrictions: Outdoor drinking and dining allowed. Smaller tourist accommodations opened (with limitations).
Indoor food and dining allowed in Gorizia, Coastal-Karst and Mura regions (with limitations).

liftSport.title: Sport
liftSport.description:
Easing of restrictions: all trainings in groups up to 10 and all competition (w/o spectators).
All schools opened, recommended model C for university.

liftHotels.title: Hotels
liftHotels.description:
Easing of restrictions: larger hotels with 50% capacity.
One person per 20 sq m in indoor public spaces (was 30 sq m).

liftGatherings50.title: Up to 50
liftGatherings50.description: Easing of restrictions: gathering up to 50 people.

liftHighSchools2.title: H.schools
liftHighSchools2.description:
Easing of restrictions: high schools and universities. Sport and culture events with spectators (with test).
Camping up to 70% capacity. Bars and restaurants opened from 5AM to 10PM.

liftGatherings.title: Gatherings
liftGatherings.description: Easing of restrictions: no limitations on public gatherings and events with required interpersonal distance.

liftCapacity75p.description: Easing of restrictions: larger hotels, culture and sport events can operate with 75% capacity.

liftServicesAll.title: Services
liftServicesAll.description: Easing restrictions: almost all services open, no restrictions on opening hours for shops and restaurants.

liftMasksOnEvents.title: Masks
liftMasksOnEvents.description:
Easing restrictions: no mask requirement at public cultural and sporting events and in restaurants, congresses and gaming salons,
but only for people who are tested, recovered or vaccinated. Relaxation of capacity restrictions at cultural and sporting events.

masksOnEvents.title: Masks🎭
masksOnEvents.description: Mask requirement at public cultural events.

pctSports.title: RVT⛹️
pctSports.description: RVT (recovered, vaccinated, tested) condition must be met by all attendees of organized recreational activities.

pctContacts.title: RVT
pctContacts.description: RVT (recovered, vaccinated, tested) condition must be met by all persons who come into direct contact with other persons in the course of their work.

pctEverywhere.title: RVT!
pctEverywhere.description: RVT (recovered, vaccinated, tested) condition must be met by all those who perform the work and all users of the services.

liftMasksRV.title: Masks
liftMasksRV.description: Easing restrictions: no mask requirement in environment where all participants are vaccinated or recovered and in indoor public spaces where food and drinks are being served.

gatherings3.title: Gatherings
gatherings3.description:
Prohibition of gathering (except for close family members), no celebrations.
Restaurants and bars allowed from 5AM to 10PM (seated service only).
Restrictions of culture and sport events (only indoors, seated with free seat between spectators).

liftQuarantineAll.title: Quarantine
liftQuarantineAll.description: Easing of restrictions: no quarantine after close contact

liftPCT.title: RVT
liftPCT.description:
Easing of restrictions: all restrictions removed, only masks required indoors.
RVT (recovered, vaccinated, tested) condition required only in healthcare, social protection institutions and prisons.

liftMasksSchools.title: Masks
liftMasksSchools.description: Easing restrictions: masks are no longer mandatory in schools and colleges.

liftMasksInside.title: Masks
liftMasksInside.description:
Easing restrictions: masks are no longer mandatory indoors.
Masks are still mandatory in healthcare and social welfare institutions.

liftEverything.description:
Easing restrictions: termination of all restrictions.
Follow recommendations of National Institute of Public Health (NIJZ).

noHospitalData.description:
Cessation of data collection on hospitalized patients.
Stopping the #OstaniZdrav app.

restrictionsPage.title: Measures and restrictions
restrictionsPage.description: Using the available data sources, we tried to collect and summarize the currently valid measures adopted by the Slovenian government in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, especially in selected areas that are most relevant to everyday life. The information available through this COVID-19 Tracker, including links to other sites, is collected from a number of official sources with which we are not affiliated, so it should be borne in mind that they are for information purposes only and may change from time to time. The tracker therefore does not guarantee the accuracy and completeness of the information collected on the measures and expressly disclaims any responsibility for further interpretations that cite our data as a source.

faq.intro: _The purpose of the Sledilnik project and all its statistical graphs and tables/presentations is to display all existing data about the COVID-19 epidemic in Slovenia in an understandable fashion. We've compiled some of the most frequently asked questions. The FAQ list is not exhaustive at this moment, but it is updated frequently so keep checking back. In case of any questions, please contact us: info@slednik.org. (We also look forward to your compliments, feedback, or suggestions!)_

why-sledilnik.question: Why Sledilnik?
why-sledilnik.answer: Our goal is to help understand the spread of the virus and to help raise awareness, responsiveness, and the effectiveness of the measures implemented to curb the virus. You can find more about the project in the [About tab](/en/about).

virus-vs-disease.question: What is the difference between SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19?
virus-vs-disease.answer: **SARS-CoV-2** is the abbreviation for ‘Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2’ – it is the internationally accepted name of the virus that causes the disease named **COVID-19**. The latter name is also an acronym, coined from the words COrona VIrus Disease, and 2019, the year when the disease first erupted.

confirmed-cases.question: What is the difference between ‘new cases’ and ‘confirmed cases’?
confirmed-cases.answer: Terminology in use on Sledilnik is explained under [What does it mean](#chart-terminology). According to the WHO definition, a *confirmed case* is a person with laboratory confirmation of COVID-19 infection, irrespective of clinical signs and symptoms. Other terms, such as newly infected, may appear in the media but are not used in our graphs. All terms used by Sledilnik are explained in these FAQ.

all-infected.question: Is it possible to get statistical information on all infected persons, even the asymptomatic cases?
all-infected.answer: Unfortunately, this data is unavailable for now. There are several reasons: Previously, tests have only covered a certain proportion of the population (patients with signs and symptoms of acute respiratory infection who may need hospital treatment, healthcare professionals, retirement home residents with respiratory symptoms, and people above 60 if their doctor so requires). Even though now the testing guidance for COVID-19 is expanded to include anyone displaying symptoms of the disease, many might be carriers with no or only mild symptoms. For this reason, our statistics can cover only part of the population that clearly shows signs of infection. Thus, the younger and the untested populations are disproportionately represented. Data for asymptomatic patients who do not show symptoms and are not recorded anywhere can therefore not be obtained.

other-countries.question: Where can I find a comparison between Slovenia and other countries?
other-countries.answer:
You can find [a comparison graph](/en/stats#countries-chart) at the very bottom of the dashboard. The graph displays a comparison between Slovenia and different clusters of countries in relation to the *number of deaths* caused by COVID-19 *per million inhabitants*.
The clusters of countries that are compared to Slovenia are as follows:
-   Neighboring countries (excluding Italy)
-   Critical countries (EU)
-   Critical countries (global)
-   Nordic countries
-   ex-Yugoslavian countries
-   East Asian countries and Oceania

The graph is arranged chronologically, from January 1, from the first death, and from the first death per million, respectively. You can change the view of different chronological displays of comparisons of different clusters of countries by clicking on the appropriate tabs.

english-translation.question: Is your webpage available in English?
english-translation.answer: Currently, only the [About part](/en/about) and these FAQ are available, while the rest of the website is yet to be fully translated. However, both the text part and the source code are available as open source if you're interested in helping us translate. All the [data in the database](https://github.com/sledilnik) is already marked with English tags, so its international use (export) is also possible.

are-you-paid.question: Are you paid for creating the dashboard (charts, tables, models)?
are-you-paid.answer: Not at all. Sledilnik is a non-profit initiative created to support the ongoing compiling and editing of key data on the spread of the coronavirus in Slovenia. Our database is public and freely available, free of charge, and non-commercial, and will remain so. Please check [How can I obtain and use your database?](#data-usage)

tech-used.question: Which tools did you use to build the website/web app?
tech-used.answer: The site is in JavaScript using Vue.js, the visualizations and graphs are made in F# using Highcharts libraries, and the project is open and available on [GitHub – Sledilnik](https://github.com/sledilnik).

data-reliability.question: Are your data and visualizations reliable?
data-reliability.answer:
Data is collected from verified public sources, which are listed on the [Data page](/en/data).

Sledilnik receives official data on COVID-19 directly from the Ministry of Health, the NIJZ (National Institute for Public Health), and other national health institutions. The Sledilnik team does not guarantee the accuracy of the original data and publishes solely data obtained from official sources or the media, but we do cross-check if all data is correct and consistent with the given source.

data-collection.question: How do you collect and edit the data?
data-collection.answer:
[The database](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1N1qLMoWyi3WFGhIpPFzKsFmVE0IwNP3elb_c18t2DwY/edit#gid=0) is built from the NIJZ source data (by category). Data by region and age is processed with delay and is finally updated once the ongoing epidemiological demographic research results are known. The municipalities are tracked in the [Kraji (Municipalities) table](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1N1qLMoWyi3WFGhIpPFzKsFmVE0IwNP3elb_c18t2DwY/edit#gid=598557107).

Editing Hospital Care Data – [Table Pacienti (Patients)](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1N1qLMoWyi3WFGhIpPFzKsFmVE0IwNP3elb_c18t2DwY/edit#gid=918589010):

- We receive daily reports and monitor the announcements of all COVID-19 hospitals  (UKC Ljubljana, UKC Maribor, UK Golnik, SB Celje) – at around 8 am.

- We monitor the number of hospitalizations: all wards, in ICUs, and on ventilators.

- We also record transitions (acceptance/dismissal) between individual stages of the disease (when detectable) from the obtained data.

- Where the transition (admission/dismissal) information is incomplete, the values are determined by inference (using a formula).

- All sources and conclusions are recorded as a commentary in individual cells (checkable).

- The data is compared with the summary data on hospitalized patients in ICU published by the Government of the Republic of Slovenia.

data-publish-time.question: When do you publish the data? Why are the dates on the visualizations different?
data-publish-time.answer:
Most data for the previous day is collected at 11:59 pm (tests, confirmed cases …), and hospitalization data is mostly obtained by 9 am every day for all hospitals. **Our data is usually updated between 10.00 and 12.00.**
When we publish updated daily data, it is available on all our distribution channels (CSV, REST, website), and we also report it on social networks ([Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/SledilnikOrg) and [Twitter](https://twitter.com/sledilnik)).

data-differences.question: Several portals display numbers of infected people that are different from yours. Why?
data-differences.answer: Sledilnik uses only validated and official data reported daily by the National Institute of Public Health (NIJZ) and all Slovenian hospitals treating COVID-19. Our data thus comes directly from verified sources, and we have also cross-compared information from the very beginning (4 March 2020). Differences usually occur because different media and portals obtain the data at different times of the day or use dubious methodology. See also [Are your data and visualizations reliable?](#data-reliability)

data-hospital-in.question: How do you obtain data on hospital admissions?
data-hospital-in.answer: Hospitals do not always report individual admissions or discharges from which we can obtain accurate data. The number of admissions is usually calculated from data on the currently hospitalized and from the difference compared to the previous day, to which we add the number of discharged and dead on a given day. We keep records of admissions and discharges in intensive care units and for connection and disconnection to/from ventilators (intubated) in a similar way.

data-hospital-out.question: How do you obtain data on hospital discharges?
data-hospital-out.answer: The information on the discharged from hospitals is calculated from data daily obtained directly from hospitals, i.e. from a verified source. We mostly get the daily number of discharges for all hospitals, from which we can deduce the number of newly admitted. See also [How do you obtain data on hospital admissions?](#data-hospital-in)

data-recovered.question: Why did you replace the number of *cured* with the number of *recovered* patients?
data-recovered.answer:
Sledilnik used to rely on official sources (Government of the Republic of Slovenia, media) for the number of cured people. Unfortunately, reports on when a person is totally cured from Covid-19 are scarce – for now, we only have few confirmed reports of "cured patients", and there is, as of yet, still no official definition of when a particular person is cured. A [COVID-19 national survey](https://covid19.biolab.si/) is currently underway at the *Institute of Microbiology and Immunology*, which will also, through voluntary sample testing, show how many people have already fallen ill and recovered from COVID-19. As it is not yet known what the potential consequences of COVID-19 could be (various studies are addressing this question and the results will not be known for a long time), and because health institutions are also talking about recovered rather than cured patients, we are thus changing both the terminology and the method of calculating the number of recoveries. See also [Do you keep an Active Case counter and do you know how many people are currently infected?](#data-active-cases))

On April 14, the Department of Health released [Priporočila za zaključek izolacije in vrnitev na delovno mesto (Recommendations for Discontinuing Isolation and Returning to Work)](https://www.zbornica-zveza.si/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/PRIPORO%C4%8CILO-Zaklju%C4%8Dek-izolacije-in-vrnitev-na-delovna-mesta-po-preboleli-bolezni-COVID-19.pdf) from which we can deduce when a person has recovered from the disease and can return to work. For people with symptoms, this is 14 days after the symptoms have subsided, and for healthcare professionals, a control swab is required after 14 days, which must be negative 2x in a row. The Government of the Republic of Slovenia regularly reports on discharges from the hospital, but we do not know if they have already recovered from the disease. The published recommendations indicate that these patients require two consecutive negative control swabs after discharge to home care in order to be considered able to return to work. [In its report](https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/covid-19-rapid-risk-assessment-coronavirus-disease-2019-ninth-update-23-april-2020.pdf) the ECDC stated that *The 14-day incidence of reported COVID-19 cases in the EU/EEA and UK, providing an estimate of the prevalence of active cases in the population…* – so we chose the 14-day period as the time when the average confirmed case can still be counted as an *active case*.

We noticed that the [Worldometer](https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/#countries) was reporting recovery numbers, but unfortunately we were unable to obtain data on where this information was coming from. Also, some other sources simply combine survivors with the number of discharged patients from hospitals. Since we believe that these two categories are interchangeable, we have decided to present them separately; these are the *Discharged from Hospital* and *Recovered* indicators.

*Note: The calculation of recoveries was changed on 9 May 2020. We now consider a patient has recovered in 14 days after their infection was confirmed (previously 21 days), so there was be a noticeable jump in the number of survivors. Please take this difference into account when estimating the number of survivors. A more detailed explanation of the changed calculation is available in the Medium article [Od potrjeno okuženih do prebolelih (From Confirmed Case to Recovery )](https://medium.com/@sledilnik/94c81674718e).*

data-active-cases.question: Do you keep an Active Case counter and do you know how many people are currently infected?
data-active-cases.answer:
Yes, these indicators have been graphically displayed as **Active Cases** and **Recovered (total)** from the end of April.


These visualizations are not data from public sources; both indicators show the calculated value on the basis of official data, so they are indicated by a dashed line for easier distinguishing. The value of the active cases is calculated by simply subtracting the official data for the relevant category, the value of the Recovered (total) reflects the status of all confirmed cases three weeks ago (minus the dead). The number of recoveries is a simple estimate based on the value of all those confirmed infected in the past – based on the assumption that patients recover from the disease on average within 14 days (source: [the ECDC Report](https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/covid-19-rapid-risk-assessment-coronavirus-disease-2019-ninth-update-23-april-2020.pdf)); thus, the number of recoveries on a given day equals the number of all confirmed cases three weeks prior to a given date, from which the number of deaths by that day is deducted. This simplified estimation does not take into account the more serious cases of COVID-19 with longer recovery times.

*Note: The calculation of recoveries was changed on 9 May 2020. We now consider a patient has recovered in 14 days after their infection was confirmed (previously 21 days), so there was be a noticeable jump in the number of survivors. Please take this difference into account when estimating the number of survivors. A more detailed explanation of the changed calculation is available in the Medium article [Od potrjeno okuženih do prebolelih (From Confirmed Case to Recovery )](https://medium.com/@sledilnik/94c81674718e).*

Value formula:
- Recovered (total) = Confirmed cases (total) 21 days ago – Died (total) by the day of calculation

- Active cases = Confirmed cases (total) - Recovered (total) - Died (total)

data-contribute.question: How can users get actively involved in data gathering? How can I participate?
data-contribute.answer:
You can voluntarily help by collecting and verifying data from the media (as well as from the field), with statistical and other analyzes, etc. Contact us at info@sledilnik.org if you’d like to participate.

Sledilnik does not collect users’ personal information nor information that individuals would like to share about their condition or hospital status.

data-usage.question: How can I obtain and use your database?
data-usage.answer:
Our database is public and freely available in the form of  [**CSV files**, **REST API**, and **Google Sheet**](/en/data). Kindly let us know the purpose for which you will use the information and make sure you include Sledilnik as the source of your data.

Since all the data in the database is already marked with English tags (see also [Is your webpage available in English?](#english-translation)), their international use (export, display) is also possible.

chart-usage.question: Can I use your graphs on my website? How?
chart-usage.answer: Sure! You can embed any graph or display on your site – citing the source, of course. [Click here](/en/embed) and select the graph you want to embed from the list.

chart-infocard-percent.question: What do the percentages in the infocards at the top of the webpage mean?
chart-infocard-percent.answer: This is a percentage growth rate on a particular date in the number of newly confirmed cases compared to the previous day. If, for example, there were 16 people in the intensive care unit yesterday and today they accepted four more, that is 25% more than yesterday's situation.

metrics-comparison-chart.question: What does the “COVID-19 Situation in Slovenia” graph mean?
metrics-comparison-chart.answer:
The [graph](/en/stats#metrics-comparison-chart) shows the daily and overall dynamics of the spread of the infection from the beginning to the present. The indicators used (see [Which indicators does the “COVID-19 Situation in Slovenia” graph include?](#chart-metrics-included)) help us understand whether and how successfully we are controlling the spread of the virus. We can monitor the daily growth rate of newly confirmed cases and indirectly see if the measures work; information on the number of hospitalizations and the proportion of those in ICU shows how many people are seriously at risk from the disease, but at the same time, this data also shows us the real burden on the health system.

The breakpoints are indicated below, on the timeline: from the first confirmed case (March 4, 2020) to the measures (by keyword and date) taken to curb the spread and their relaxation. This helps us monitor the dynamics of the variables relative to the measures.

chart-metrics-included.question: Which indicators does the “COVID-19 Situation in Slovenia” graph include?
chart-metrics-included.answer:
[Graf](/en/stats#metrics-comparison-chart) vključuje:

* **Tests (per day)** = Number of tests for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 virus causing COVID-19 performed. In the first stages of the epidemic, this was an important indicator of the prevalence of the virus, but with the change in testing methodology, ie. of the tested sample, it turned into an indicator of the national health and diagnostics system’s capacity.

* **Tests (total)** = Sum of tests up to; data is useful in terms of comparison or in terms of the proportion of the entire population tested, but it can be misleading as certain individuals can be tested several times (eg. health professionals, retirement home employees, etc.).

* **Confirmed Cases (per day)** = Number of confirmed infected per day based on tests (from 21.12.2020 PCR and RAT). This indicator does not reflect the actual dynamics of newly infected people in the population, as the tests do not sample the entire population but target the at-risk people and certain occupational groups.

* **Confirmed cases (total)** = Total number of all confirmed cases by a given day.

* **Active cases** = Confirmed cases (total) – Recovered (total) – Died (total)

* **Recovered (total)** = Number of recoveries on a given day is a simple estimate equal to the number of all confirmed cases two weeks prior to a given date (assuming an average of 14 days needed to recover), from which the number of fatalities till that very date is subtracted. See also [Why did you replace the number of cured with the number of recovered patients?](#data-recovered)

* **Hospitalized** = Current number of people in hospital care (either in the ordinary ward or in the ICU).

* **Hospitalized (total) ** = Sum of hospital admissions by date.

* **ICU** = Current number of people in ICUs (intensive care units).

* **On ventilator (intubated) ** = Current number of persons in need of a ventilator and are intubated.

* **Discharged from a hospital (daily)** = Number of discharged from hospital on that day.

* **Discharged from hospital (total)** = Sum of all discharged from a hospital up to this day.

* **Deaths (per day) ** = Number of deaths due to COVID-19 on that day.

* **Deaths (total) ** = Sum of all deaths to date.

chart-terminology.question: What does it mean?
chart-terminology.answer:
Sledilnik uses terminology which is consistent with the official directives of the WHO and ECDC (European Center for Disease Prevention and Control). We use the following tags in the displays:
* **Confirmed cases** = This is the number of people who tested positive for the SARS-CoV-2 virus (from 21.12.2020 PCR and RAT). Since the number of confirmed cases depends solely on testing, the number of confirmed cases is significantly lower than the actual number of infected people.

* **Hospitalized** = This is the number of confirmed cases such severe symptoms of COVID-19 that they have been admitted to hospital.

* **In ICU** = Indicates the number of hospitalized persons who are at risk of death because of the severe symptoms of COVID-19 and require placement in the intensive care unit. This is a subset of the *Hospitalized* category.

* **On ventilator (intubated)** = Indicates the number of hospitalized persons in the intensive care unit who require a ventilator to breathe and are intubated. It is a subset of the *Intensive Care* and *Hospitalized* categories.

* **Recovered** = This is an estimate of the number confirmed cases that are expected to have recovered after 14 days. The number of recoveries is thus equal to the number of all confirmed cases two weeks prior – assuming that the disease should be overcome within 14 days – from which the number of deaths by that given day is subtracted. (See also the question [Why did you replace the number of cured with the number of recovered patients?](#data-recovered)

cases-chart.question: What are the Closed cases and what are the Active cases?
cases-chart.answer:
All confirmed cases are shown in the [Confirmed Cases graph](/en/stats#cases-chart). In order to be able to monitor the epidemic, it is important to know how many are still infected. For this reason, we use the following terminology:

**Closed cases**  are the sum of all confirmed cases who are no longer infected with the virus, that is, the recovered and the deceased.

**Active cases** are all confirmed virus infections that still haven’t recovered (are still infected with the virus). See also
 [Which indicators does the “COVID-19 Situation in Slovenia” graph include?](#chart-metrics-included)

chart-phases.question: What do the different phases (phases 1-18) in the graph mean?
chart-phases.answer:
The vertical lines divide the stages, delimited by the dates, when the authorities changed the way information about the spread of the infection was collected (the test method was changed, self-isolation interventions were introduced, bans on gathering and movement of persons, and mandatory basic protection were required).

The phases are shown because the change in testing methodology has also changed the importance of certain indicators by which the prevalence of infections can be judged.

* **Phase 1 (March 4-12, 2020)**: The first cases of infection in Slovenia are recorded. All cases are followed, all contacts are tested.

* **Phase 2 (March 13-19, 2020)**: The testing methodology is changed, and self-isolation and social distancing measures are introduced.

* **Phase 3 (March 20-April 7)**: The testing methodology is revised and a ban on gathering more than five people in public areas is put in place.

* **Phase 4 (April 8-15)**: New change in testing methodology – people with mild symptoms from households with more than one respiratory infections are also tested.

* **Phase 5 (April 15-21)**: New change in testing methodology – re-testing, if possible, of **all suspected SARS-CoV-2 virus infections**.

* ** Phase 6 (April 21–May 15**: New change in testing methodology – All persons **suspected of being infected with SARS-CoV-2** are tested again. A national survey of 3000 randomly sampled persons (additional testing, blood testing for the presence of antibodies) begins.

* **Phase 7 (May 15–present)**: The Slovenian government called an official end to its coronavirus epidemic – a quarantine of at least 14 days will remain in place for people from non-EU states, except for some exemptions (diplomats, cargo). Citizens still have to follow basic rules to prevent a possible spread of infection.

patients-chart.question: What does the “Hospitalizations” graph tell us?
patients-chart.answer:
The [graph](/en/stats#patients-chart) in the default view *All Hospitals* shows us the whole picture of hospitalizations by date arranged by the condition of patients: columns with a positive value (those above the horizontal axis) show the number admitted to hospital, the number hospitalized, shades of red are used to demark individuals in ICUs, specifically depicting how many of these are in critical condition on the ventilators (intubated). Columns with a negative value (those below the horizontal axis) show the number of discharges and deaths that day. You can also select specific hospital and see only hospitalizations there. If you select the *By Hospitals* view below, you can see the number of people in hospital care by day for each of the COVID-19 hospitals.
The graph can offer a good insight into the workload of hospitals and can be the basis for assessing hospital capacity and planning their possible increase.

ratios-chart.question: What does the “Share of Serious Cases” graph tell us?
ratios-chart.answer:
[Graf](/en/stats#ratios-chart) prikazuje deleže resnih primerov bolezni in smrtnosti v treh različnih prikazih. Vsi podatki so prikazani kot procent (%).

(*Resni primeri*) nam kaže hospitalizirane, v intenzivni enoti, na respiratorju (intubirani) in umrle kot delež vseh potrjeno okuženih. Iz tega je razvidno kako velik delež vseh potrjeno okuženih oseb ima težjo obliko bolezni, ki zahteva hospitalizacijo, sprejem v intenzivno enoto in uporabo respiratorja.

(*Hospitalizirani*) nam kaže osebe v intenzivni enoti, na respiratorju in umrle v bolnišnici kot delež vseh hospitaliziranih. Ta prikaz ponazori na kakšnem oddelku in kakšno obravnavo potrebujejo hospitalizirani bolniki.

(*Smrtnost*) nam pokaže delež smrti v bolnišnici glede na vse umrle in delež smrti v intenzivni enoti glede na vse umrle v bolnišnici - prikazano s polno črto. Prikaz nam tudi prikaže Smrtnost v bolnišnici (koliko oseb umre glede na vse hospitalizirane) in Smrtnost v intenzivni enoti (koliko oseb umre glede na vse sprejete v intenzivno enoto) - prikazano s črtkano črto.

Graf je uporaben za razumevanje obravnave bolnikov v Sloveniji in primerjave z ostalimi državami (glede na njihova poročila).

hcenters-chart.question: What does the “Healthcare Center Treatment” graph mean?
hcenters-chart.answer:
The [graph](/en/stats#hcenters-chart) shows the treatment of suspicions of COVID-19 in healthcare centers (primary health care level). You can show data for whole country or select specific region. Healthcare centers are the first entry point for taking swabs to be tested for the presence of the virus, so an increase in the number of suspicions and referrals to self-isolation may be an early indicator that new outbreaks have occurred.

The graph thus shows the number of all emergency medical visits (also for other diseases) in healthcare centers (see notes below), the number of suspected cases of COVID-19 based on the number of examinations at the COVID-19 entry point, and all suspicions of infections based on telephone conversation with suspected infected patients. Some people may be recorded several times, first by telephone and then during the examination. We also show the total number of referrals to self-isolation.

*Note 1: in some municipalities, the control point for COVID-19 is within the hospital premises (for example the Celje and Novo mesto General Hospitals). Data before 14.4. is not available for these general hospitals.
Note 2: the methodology for recording suspicions of inspections via telephone conversation has changed, so all suspicions were initially recorded. Since April 23, however, only those suspicions via telephone conversation have been recorded, where no examination and swabbing (testing) was ordered. Therefore it is possible that there are differences in how individual healthcare centers report this data and that this number is too high.*

When reporting the number of tests performed, all tests (including repeated tests) are recorded. The number of positive tests therefore includes all positive tests – the same person can be tested several times and counted as positive several times. The number of tests performed may therefore be greater than the number of positive tests reported by laboratories (there, each person is recorded only once). See also [What does the “Testing” graph tell us?](#tests-charts)

tests-chart.question: What does the “Testing” graph tell us?
tests-chart.answer:
The [graph](/en/stats#tests-chart) shows the total number of regular tests (the *Regular PCR* display), and the national IMI survey tests (by selecting the *Survey* display). The columns show the number of negative and positive tests on a specific day, and the curve shows the daily percentage of positive tests.

Since December 2020 we are also tracking rapid antigen tests (RAT) - see *Regular RAT* display.

infections-chart.question: What does the “Structure of Confirmed Cases” graph tell us?
infections-chart.answer:
The [graph](/en/stats#infections-chart)provides an insight into the daily share of confirmed cases from high-risk groups or employees in high-risk areas. Due to insufficiently accurate input data on confirmed infections, daily values (By days (average)) are shown as a moving average of 7 days. The sum of the values on a particular day, from 3 days prior, and 3 days after, is divided by 7. Therefore, the graph shows the situation four days before a specific day, and in this way we get a better idea of trends by individual groups. If we select the *Total* or *Relative* display, we will jump from the confirmed cases curve to the histogram, which shows the number of confirmed infected persons within each category on a given day.

The increase in infected healthcare workers does not mean that they were discovered exactly on that day; they may have been positive before but information on their status was obtained subsequently. The *Retirement Home Employees* category includes healthcare workers, associates, and external assistance (health students), so the daily data on healthcare workers (blue curve or columns) are reduced accordingly. This means that the number of health professionals is a very conservative estimate.

spread-chart.question: What does the “Growth of Confirmed Cases” graph mean?
spread-chart.answer: The [graph](/en/stats#spread-chart) tells us how many new confirmed cases of infections there were on a given day, where the WHO and the [ECDC definition](https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/case-definition-and-european-surveillance-human-infection-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov) that confirmed cases are “persons with a lab confirmation of infection with COVID-19” is followed. From December 21, 2020 this includes cases confirmed with rapid antigen tests (RAT). As the number of confirmed cases still depends on testing, the data in confirmed cases is estimated to be much smaller that the actual number of infected people.

regions-chart.question: What does the “By Region” tell us?
regions-chart.answer: The [graph](/en/stats#regions-chart) shows the dynamics of growth of confirmed cases by selected regions. Individual regions can be easily compared by selecting the ones you want shown on the graph by clicking on specific regions below the graph. From the curve, we can quickly see which regions have the most and which the least confirmed cases and how this number has changed over time.

map-chart.question: What does the “Municipality Map” tell us?
map-chart.answer:
The [map](/en/stats#map-chart) shows us the epidemiological picture of individual municipalities, as it allows the display of *Confirmed Cases* (red shades) or the *Dead* (gray shades). When showing confirmed cases, we can see which municipalities are the most "healthy" (white) and which are currently the more "infected" (red shades) – if new cases are still appearing or not - and relative to the share of the population (Proportion of population is the default display). On the left, we can use the filter (1, 7, 14 or 21 days) to determine for what period of time we view data on new confirmed cases or deaths. For those municipalities where new cases are still being confirmed, we can conclude that the epidemic is still active. (Of course, this does not necessarily mean that the virus is not present in municipalities without new confirmed cases, but it is an indicator of the "health" of a certain area.) More details are available in the Medium article [Kje so “zdrave” občine? (Where Are the ‘Healthy’ Municipalities?)](https://medium.com/sledilnik/kje-so-zdrave-občine-613afc42b023)

By clicking on *Absolute* in the upper right corner, we can change the display and see the total number of newly confirmed cases or deaths in a selected time frame (1, 7, 14 or 21 days) in municipalities according to how they are painted.

municipalities-chart.question: What does the chart “Cases by Municipalities” show us?
municipalities-chart.answer:
The [chart](/en/stats#municipalities-chart) shows individual municipalities in columns in more detail with the number of confirmed cases by days, with active cases, recoveries (assessment) and deaths in each municipality. Below the municipality you can find the information about the time since the last confirmed case. Municipalities are classified according to when the last confirmed case was recorded there, from which we can conclude which municipalities are currently more “infected” and which are “healthier” than others.

The display can be changed by selecting different views above the graph: if you select the *Active* display, the municipalities will be sorted according to the current assessment of active cases; or if you select *All*, then the municipalities will be arranged by the largest total number of confirmed cases. If you choose *All Regions* from the dropdown menu, then confirmed cases will be shown in the municipalities belonging to that region. You can also easily search for a municipality by entering its name in the *Find Municipality* browser.

*Note: the assessment of recoveries and active cases is done 14 days after the infection was confirmed, if and when the disease is in its mild form. However, if an individual is hospitalized, this recovery will last longer, but in this case the individual is not dangerous to the environment because he is in hospital. Since we do not take into account the hospitalized in the municipality presentation, it is possible that the sum of active cases by municipality does not match the estimate of the active cases for the whole country. See also [Do you keep an Active Case counter and do you know how many people are currently infected?](#data-active-cases)*

phase-diagram-chart.question: What does the "Phase diagram" graph mean?
phase-diagram-chart.answer:
[Phase diagram](/sl/stats#phase-diagram-chart) is a visualization which shows the state of the epidemic in a coordinate space that does not have time as one of its axis; axes are used for quantities that help visualize and compare the state of the epidemic regardless of the time at which this state was reached. The position of a point in such a visualization changes with time, typically following predictable patterns; this can help us understand the dynamics and decipher the phase of the epidemic. The diagram has two displays: "Total vs. week" and "Incidence growth".

**Total vs. weekly** shows the total number of cases on the x axis, and new cases in the last week on the y axis. Both axes are logarithmic. When an epidemic grows exponentially, the point on this diagram will move upwards and to the right in a straight line; the faster the exponential growth, the steeper the slope of this line. When the growth slows down, the point first starts moving horizontally (a longer period of such dynamics would mean a plateau - linear growth of new cases), and with strong deceleration of the epidemic the curve turns sharply downwards and stops when the epidemic completes.

**Incidence growth** shows the state of the epidemic using 7-day incidence on the x axis and its relative weekly growth on the y axis. Horizontal position of the point shows the spread of the virus in the population, while vertical position is related to the speed of the epidemic's exponential growth. When the point is above 100% vertically, the epidemic is growing exponentially and the point will move towards the right (incidence will increase). When the point is below 100%, the epidemic is dying out, and the point will move towards the left.

age-groups-chart.question: What does the “Age Groups” graph show?

countries-chart.question: What does the “Comparison by Country” graph show?
countries-chart.answer: The [chart](/en/stats#countries-chart) shows a comparison between Slovenia and different groups of countries in terms of the number of deaths due to COVID-19 per million inhabitants. The graph is arranged chronologically. You can change the view of different chronological displays of comparisons of different clusters of countries by clicking on the appropriate tabs below.

chart-reality.question: Do your graphs represent the real picture?
chart-reality.answer:
Yes, as far as they can, given the limitations of the current displays and of the data itself: the graphs on this page only show what can be deduced from the information given. For example, the total number of tests represents the number of tests performed to date, but does not reflect the total number of people tested, as some people, such as healthcare professionals and people suspected of being infected, have been repeatedly tested.

However, the number of confirmed cases depends solely on testing. Since the majority of infected people, who have mild or no symptoms, have not been tested for COVID-19 at all, the number of confirmed cases is significantly lower than the actual number of infected people (from 21.12.2020 people testing positive on rapid antigen tests (RAT) also count as confirmed cases).

chart-correlation.question: What does the "Correlation between confirmed cases, hospitalization, and deaths" graph mean?
chart-correlation.answer:
The [correlation graph](/en/stats#metrics-correlation-chart) shows the temporal correlation between the number of confirmed cases (from 21.12.2020 PCR and RAT), the number of hospitalized patients with, and the number of deaths caused by COVID-19. Each of the three graphs is shown on its scale, as this is the easiest way to show how long after the growth of new confirmed cases of infections we can expect an increase in the number of hospitalized and how much later also an increase in death.

The graph offers two view menus. In the menu directly below the graph, you can turn an individual curve on or off by clicking on “Confirmed cases”, “Hospitalized”, or “Dead”. Under the first menu, you can switch between the seven-day average and the total number of confirmed cases, hospitalized, or deceased by clicking on the icons "By days (7-day average)" and "Total".

chart-cases-by-age-group.question: What does the "Confirmed cases by age groups" graph mean?
chart-cases-by-age-group.answer:
[Graph](/en/stats#age-groups-trends-chart) The graph divides the daily number of confirmed cases into age groups, according to ten-year age intervals. Exceptions are the first interval (0 to 4 years) and the last, open interval (85+). In the initial view, we see the absolute number of daily confirmed cases (from 21.12.2020 PCR and RAT), divided into age groups.

Below the graph are two view menus. The menu directly below the graph offers a view of an individual age group, and the menu below it also offers the possibility of switching views between absolute and relative values of different age groups in the daily number of confirmed cases and in the number of actively infected.

weekly-demographics-chart.question: What does the "Weekly Cases - Demographics" graph mean?
weekly-demographics-chart.answer:
[Weekly Cases - Demographics](/en/stats#weekly-demographics-chart) is a heatmap displaying the demographic data of confirmed cases accumulated on a weekly basis (from 21.12.2020 PCR and RAT). In the default view, the graph shows the case numbers in each age group per 100,000 people. The shades of green indicate low case numbers in the given week, whereas beige and brown colors indicate a large amount of confirmed cases.

 Clicking on the *Cases Ratio M/F* button in the lower-left corner, switches to the display of the ratio between confirmed cases amongst males and females. The color scale now ranges between blue (more male confirmed cases) and red (more female confirmed cases).

what-is-sledilnik.question: What is Sledilnik?
what-is-sledilnik.answer: [Sledilnik je projekt](/en/about) is an open-data and open-sourced project that collects, analyzes and displays some of the most useful data to better understand the spread of the coronavirus pandemic and COVID-19 disease, along with its dynamics and scope. We want to make clear graphical and statistical visualizations of what current data and reviews tell us about the spread of the virus in Slovenia, and ensure that information on the magnitude and severity of the COVID-19 problem in Slovenia becomes accessible and comprehensible to all.

how-to-help.question: I would like to help, where can I begin?
how-to-help.answer: Contact us at info@sledilnik.org and briefly describe who you are and how you can contribute to the project. Warmly welcome to help.

donation.title: I support Sledilnik
donation.intro:
Here at the **Sledilnik non-profit scientific society** we want to invite you to support our work by donating according to your means. With your help, we will be able to continue processing and analysing datasets critical to the functioning of our society, making them publicly available, increasing awareness, and improving decision-making.

Your contribution will help us continue doing what we do best: publicly offer open data and accessible analyses – creating a **better today and tomorrow for us all**. Thank you for caring!

banktransfer.description: Our activities can also be supported **by bank transfer**, with **any amount**.

success.title: Thank you for your donation
success.description:
Your donation will help us with our future work.
We kindly ask you to encourage others to donate as well.

banktransfer.description: The payment instructions are as follows:

stripe.description: Alternatively, you can make a **one-off** donation of:

success.title: Thank you for your one-time donation

stripe.description: You can support us **by credit card**. A regular monthly donation gives us a stable income and distributes your costs evenly throughout the year. You can stop your donation at any time. Just drop us a line at drustvo@sledilnik.org.

success.title: Thank you for your monthly recurring donation
success.description: If you would like to stop your recurring donation please let us know at drustvo@sledilnik.org.

companies.title: For companies
companies.description: Please contact us at drustvo@sledilnik.org to prepare a donation contract and/or other necessary documentation as required.

other.title: Other ways of support
other.description:
For a few more ways to support us from within Slovenia you might want to check out the [Slovenian translation of this page](/sl/donate).

We are always grateful for suggestions and shares of our posts on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/sledilnik), [Facebook](https://fb.me/SledilnikOrg), [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCM_Sk2GZ8vTMiyBQ0SMHgJw/videos), [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/sledilnik/) and other platforms, as well as new features and source code fixes on [GitHub](https://github.com/sledilnik).

We will appreciate it even more if you can grant us access to any open data that might be relevant for our analyses. 

If you have a different proposal for how to support our activities or for how we could cooperate, please do not hesitate and contact us at info@sledilnik.org - we will be happy to find a solution.
